summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell. The Government is responding to a defense letter and requests a limited unsealing of a prior court opinion and motion papers to review them for potential redactions, particularly of victim and witness names.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell; the letter is addressed to her.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case referenced (20 Cr. 330 (AJN)).

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The United States Attorney who submitted the letter to the court.

connections.description: Judge Nathan is presiding over the criminal case against Maxwell.
Strauss, as U.S. Attorney, is part of the prosecution team against Maxwell.

events.title: Court Denies Defense Subpoena Motion
events.description: The Court issued a sealed opinion denying defense counsel's ex parte motion for an order authorizing four Rule 17(c)(3) subpoenas.

events.title: Defense Counsel Submits Letter
events.description: Defense counsel submitted a letter to the Court regarding sealing/redaction of the August 13 opinion and motion papers.

events.title: Government Requests Limited Unsealing
events.description: The Government files this letter requesting a limited unsealing of the August 13 opinion and motion papers to review for potential redactions.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
The Silvio J. Motto Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The Government is seeking to unseal a prior court opinion and motion papers to review them for potential redactions, specifically noting the papers likely contain names of victims and potential witnesses.
The defense had filed a sealed, ex parte motion for subpoenas, which the court denied in a sealed opinion on August 13, 2021.
The defense stated they seek no redactions and believe the burden to justify redactions is on the Government.
The Government states it does not have copies of the sealed motion papers or the court's opinion, preventing it from proposing redactions.
This document highlights procedural tensions between prosecution and defense regarding the sealing of sensitive case materials.
